title: High culture: Stunning futuristic museum on peak of 7,500ft Italian mountain opens (but is the view the main attraction?)
text:
21 shares 4
View
comments
This takes high culture to another level altogether.
Everest climber Reinhold Messner has opened his sixth and last 'Messner Mountain Museum' atop the 7,500ft-tall Mount Kronplatz in South Tyrol in Italy. The striking, futuristic building features a series of tools, photographs and objects, from the explorer's life as a mountaineer.
Messner, who was the first to scale Mount Everest without supplemental oxygen, collaborated with renowned Iraqi-British architect Zaha Hadid to create the unique mountain hub which visitors can now explore.
Everest climber Reinhold Messner has opened his sixth and last Messner Mountain Museum featuring items from his life as an explorer
Climbers' paradise: The building offers 240 degree panoramic views of the Dolomites, set at 7,463 feet above sea level
The climber gained international fame for becoming the first man to climb Mount Everest without the help of oxygen
This concept image shows how engineers constructed the museum inside the rockface, with multiple levels and attractions
The museum is stuck straight through a mountain peak to protrude at multiple angles to offer unique views of the surrounding landscape
The museum isn't easy to reach - but the rewards for the effort needed to get there are considerable
The unique building is laid out on several levels, with a large proportion underground - and as a result the energy-efficient museum maintains a constant temperature level during both summer and winter.
What brings the exhibition's mountaineering theme to life, however, is the breathtaking surroundings.
The building offers 240-degree panoramic views of the Dolomites mountain range.
'The particular thing about this museum is the combination of the location, the view, and the architecture,' explained Messner.
'The theme is rock and the great faces; the original, traditional mountain climbing is to rise again here.'

The lower level has a glass-encased window which offers a viewing terrace and views of the Zillertal Alps to the Ortles-Ortler, linking the mountain world outside and the subject matter of the museum.
Guests can wander down the staircases to the different zones, or take advantage of the museum's shop or twenty-seater cinema.
There are also larger exhibits and presentations available, all centred around the theme of 'rock.'
The museum features larger exhibits, a cinema, a shop and presentations, all centred around the theme of 'rock'
The striking, futuristic building is set atop Mount Kronplatz in South Tyrol, Italy, and will house a series of tools, photographs and objects
The climber collaborated with renowned Iraqi-British architect Zaha Hadid to create the unique mountain hub, which visitors can now explore
The project is the result of a collaboration between the climber, who serves as a specialist in the history of traditional mountaineering, Hadid, and the board behind South Tyrol-SÃ¼dtirol's ski mountain, Kronplatz.
It's hoped that the project will add value not just to the Kronplatz-Plan de Corones Ski Mountain but also to the surrounding communities.
Skirama Kronplatz, the ski resort which aims to maintain the appeal of the Kronplatz Ski Mountain throughout all seasons, stated the museum was a milestone in the history of ski lift facilities.
'This project,' explained Skirama President Matthias Prugger, 'which is being implemented together with Zaha Hadid, takes us into a higher league.
'The Kronplatz demonstrates once again that visions are not only put down on paper, but are also realised.'
Guests can wander down the staircases to the different zones, or take advantage of the museum's shop or twenty-seater cinema
The unique building is laid out on several levels, with a large proportion of this underground and as a result, the energy-efficient museum maintains a constant temperature level during both summer and winter
The project is hoped to add a value, not just for the Kronplatz-Plan de Corones Ski Mountain, but also for the surrounding communities
Messner, who was the first to scale Mount Everest without supplemental oxygen, is pictured here giving a speech at the site of the museum
Messner runs five other museums in picturesque locations including MMM Ortles in Italy, which focuses on the world of ice, featuring skiing, ice-climbing and expeditions to the Poles as its themes.
Guests can also explore MMM Ripa, set inside the stunning Bruneck Castle in the Puster Valley, which has exhibitions that reflect the cultures, religions and tourism activities of mountain peoples from Asia, Africa, South America and Europe.
The other museums are MMM Firmian in Sigmundskron Castle, MMM Dolomites on Monte Rite and MMM Juval, in Juval Castle in the Vinschgau Valley.
With the opening of his sixth museum, Messner has completed his collection, which he has dubbed his 'fifteenth 8,000 metre peak'.
MMM Corones, which is located on the summit plateau of Kronplatz, is dedicated to the supreme discipline of mountaineering
The lower level has a glass-encased window which offers a viewing terrace and views of the Zillertal Alps to the Ortles-Ortler, providing a reference between the mountain world outside and the theme of the museum
The project is the result of a collaboration between the climber, who serves as a specialist in the history of traditional mountaineering, architect Zaha Hadid, and the tourism board behind ski mountain, Kronplatz
The museum's interior is just as striking as the exterior, with fascinating exhibitions and artwork
Messner is considered the first person to complete all of the 14 mountains with peaks over 26,000 ft above sea level around the globe
With the opening of his sixth museum, Messner called the collection his 'fifteenth 8,000 metre peak'
Messner reportedly chose the museum's location due to the 'unique location in a true melting pot of the region's Ladin, Italian, and German-speaking population'
